results.title: Billie in Oakleigh
results.brief_description:
A short home-movie shot in slow-motion of the graceful and elegant movements of Billie O’Keefe as she performs a gymnastic routine in the urban landscape of Oxford Street, Oakleigh.
This poetic film is backed by the haunting soundtrack of celtic music played by Cath Connelly (harp) and Greg Hunt (fiddle).

results.title: Billal
results.creator_credit: Tom Zubrycki, Australian Film Commission, ABC-TV (Australia) and AFFC
results.brief_description: Tom Zubrycki was intending to make a documentary film about unemployed youth in Sydney’s western suburbs when he came across the Etters, a Lebanese Muslim family who had migrated to Australia. What was initially meant to be a film exploring migration and class relationships in urban Australia became something else when the second son, Billal, was the victim of a racially motivated attack which left him brain damaged. As Zubrycki allows his camera to explore each individual family member’s response to the accident, the film becomes an exploration of grief and suffering, and a tribute to the young man’s attempt to adjust to his new situation. Billal and his family infuse their stories with humour and insight, and as the film explores Billal’s rehabilitation, it also becomes an absurd commentary on the under-resourced Australian public health system. “Billal” is then a documentary which is largely about family, and of how a family deals with the tragic consequences of violence. But it is also, of course, a documentary which with subtlety and piquancy, illuminates the destructive effects of racism.

results.title: Bill Tilden's advanced tennis
results.creator_credit: Julian Peyser and New Official Films
results.brief_description: Bill Tilden narrates and demonstrates advanced techniques of tennis, including net game, foot work, smash, service and volley. Front, back, aside and overhead views permit study of his playing technique from a variety of angles.

results.title: Bill Reid
results.creator_credit: Jack Long, George Johnson, Penni Jacques and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film shows British Columbian Metis artist Bill Reid, jeweller and wood carver, at work on a totem pole in the Haida Indian tradition and the gradual transformation of a bare cedar trunk into a richly carved pole is demonstrated. The totem pole is a gift of the artist to the people of Skidegate, Queen Charlotte Islands. Particularly moving is the raising of the pole by the villagers, as Bill Reid stands by.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jack Long, George Johnson, Penni Jacques and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Bill Onus
results.brief_description: To Bill Onus, sharing his culture was an act of resistance and reclamation of power. The Yorta Yorta activist, artist and entrepreneur had roles in several Australian films, documented Aboriginal life through home movies and is likely one of the first Aboriginal filmmakers.

constellations_primary.name: Setting the record straight
constellations_primary.description: For too long, the history of Australia was only told in mainstream films through a white lens. First Nations people have used the camera as a means of truth-telling and setting the record straight for decades.

results.description: To Bill Onus (1906-68), sharing his culture was an act of resistance and reclamation of power. From the 1930s, the Wiradjuri and Yorta Yorta activist, artist and entrepreneur had roles in several Australian films, documented Aboriginal life through home movies and is likely one of the first Aboriginal filmmakers, with a recently discovered silent 1946 film credited to him. Through Forgotten People (1967) and Alcheringa (1962), Bill demonstrated his ongoing commitment to self-representation through screen culture. He helped establish the Aborigines Advancement League and campaigned for the ‘YES’ vote in the 1967 Referendum. Through his factory and shop, Aboriginal Enterprises, he shared his art and culture, selling boomerangs and other pieces.
description_for_label: To Bill Onus (1906-68), sharing his culture was an act of resistance and reclamation of power. From the 1930s, the Wiradjuri and Yorta Yorta activist, artist and entrepreneur had roles in several Australian films, documented Aboriginal life through home movies and is likely one of the first Aboriginal filmmakers, with a recently discovered silent 1946 film credited to him. Through Forgotten People (1967) and Alcheringa (1962), Bill demonstrated his ongoing commitment to self-representation through screen culture. He helped establish the Aborigines Advancement League and campaigned for the ‘YES’ vote in the 1967 Referendum. Through his factory and shop, Aboriginal Enterprises, he shared his art and culture, selling boomerangs and other pieces.

results.title: Bill Morrison: 8 films
results.brief_description: Bill Morrison is an award winning filmmaker whose films are held in the permanent collection of the Museum of Modern Art. His short experimental films, where memory and history are important themes, use evocative monochrome imagery rhythmically edited together. Morrison, who was originally a painter, found the film medium more spiritually effective on a larger and captive audience. His use of found footage and high contrast almost abstract black and white footage arranged to create an atmospheric dreaminess with textural ghostly and poetic visions present an objective and meditative view. The Duchamp inspired experiments use machinery and in particular film related machinery like the machine that punches the sprocket holes in 35mm film and even the projector workings. Diagrams animated reveal the way a shutter works on a projector. Images of zoetropes, film storage and film processing machines are cut together with a rhythm where the machines of films become the subject. Film edge numbers and countdown leaders are strong images. There is interesting footage of the Library of Congress and its collection of paper film used in the piece “The Film of her”. There is a mild narrative compared to his earlier semi abstract films.

results.title: Bill Loosley's heat pump
results.creator_credit: Ken McCready, Roman Bittman and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Shows thermal engineer Bill Loosely’s simple design for beating the high costs of heating. Animation and explanations by Loosely himself are used to show how he used copper tubing and freon gas to collect warmth from the ground outside and pump it through his house. Suitable for upper secondary level.
